Student Employment Center formed
By ANDREW LASHLEY
The Student Council has
passed a resolution providing for
a permanent Student
Employment Center.
The Employment Center 'now
awaits funding by the University,
which will come through
Homewood Vice President
George Benton's office.
The service, as proposed,
would be staffed by a permanent
administrator who would be
assisted by five or six students
working part time. Dean of
Students, Robert Fitzpatrick,
hopes the center will begin,
preliminary operation in
February 1973.
Andy Savitz, President of the
Student Council, stated that the
proposal came about as a result
of the tuition hike scheduled for
September 1973.
"When the tuition hike was
approved we looked for ways to

compensate for the added
expense. Increased financial aid
and more part-time jobs for
undergraduates seemed a
workable solution," Savitz
commented.
Fitzpatrick characterized the
University's role in the creation
of such a center as necessary,
citing the tuition increase and
federal cutbacks on the
Work -Study Program as
increasing the economic burden
on Hopkins undergraduates.
"I think that the University
has a responsibility that goes
beyond the classroom. Therefore
if we don't want to limit the
University to those who can pay,
then we have to accept
responsibility for those who
can't. I think a University
composed entirely of rich people
would be one of the worst
educational possibilities
imaginable," the Dean

commented.
Fitzpatrick and Savitz stressed
the fact that the Employment
Center would be an integral part
of an expanded financial aid
system. Such a program, still in
early planning stages, would be
formulated to meet the
increasing financial burden
imposed by tuition and living
costs. The program would entail
consolidation and expansion of
the existing Financial Aid Office.
The Student Employment
Center would assist students in
finding jobs on and off campus.
"Basically what we want is for
the University to hire a full time
employee whose job would be to
find work for undergraduates on
or off campus. This employee
would be aided by five or six
students, working on a part time
basis, in rounding up jobs and
making employment information
available," Savitz explained.

Four Homewood buildings are topped

Small structures built on the roofs of
buildings. these cupolas are intended to
serve absolutely no purpose whatsoever

off" to the neoclassic symmetry of
Georgian buildings. They supply a nice
base for weathervanes. They would also
make nice bell towers, but, judging from
the local examples. this rarely occurred to
anyone.
Though both the Shriver Hall and Barn
cupolas are graced with vanes, the cupolas
were not built for that purpose. (it's
always raining in Baltimore. no matter
which direction the wind is blowing.)

deductive elimination, the cupolas were
evidently planned for the strictly artistic
qualities that they would add to the
buildings.
After carefully observing the cupolas at
Homewood. one can only shake his head
and sigh, "They shudda stuck to
weathervanes." The word "cupola" is
Latin for "little tub," but who would
have thought that the Hopkins architects
would have taken their etymology so
seriously?
Only the barn is enhanced by its
cupola. Significantly, this is the only
building with a cupola that was not
planned by the University. The simple,

graceful symmetry of the theatre is
heightened by a cupola that is
proportional to the building and thus
complements it. Unfortunately, the same
cannot be said about the other three
cupolas. Since students are unaware of
the existence of Latrobe Hall, students
are more than likely unaware of the
existence of Latrobe Hall's cupola, an
insignificant nothing that does absolutely
nil for an already nondescript building.

what exactly is that thing rising so
majestically and phallically out of Shriver
Hall? If it were a little bit taller it would
have made a nice lighthouse.

their way out at Hopkins. Mr. John
Peach, Director of Physical Planning for
the Homewood campus, pointed out that
none of the latest buildings constructed
on campus have cupolas. The reason for
this, he explained, is that "the University
is gradually making the transition from
the Georgian style to the contemporary
style." Peach added that bell towers and
cupolas serve only frivolous purposes, and
that the University does not have the
money to build them. But judging from
Hopkins' last step in the transition,
Garland Hall. even a cupolated
monstrosity would be a vast
improvement.

Westminster Chimes, or parts therof,

electrician. And once a year, during the

turned off.

unfortunately fallen by the wayside.
